text: indian regulators have temporarily shut
down several coal-fired power plants
around the capital delhi it's in an
effort to tackle the toxic smog that's
shrouding the city a partial lockdown is
already in place in delhi and its
suburbs schools colleges are shot until
further notice and all non-essential
construction work will stop until sunday
well it follows a warning from india's
meteorological department that dangerous
levels of air pollution are likely to
persist well let's cross over to delhi
to speak to our correspondent reginally
vardyanathan live now regina we were
speaking about this on monday and you
described you gave that really graphic
description of living with smog in this
time in delhi and around delhi we've now
had these measures about the temporary
closure of several coal-fired power
plants
yeah i mean those measures have come in
but the pollution readings here are
still incredibly high cassia um i was
just checking before i came on air and
it's around 300 in the area that i'm in
the air quality index and the who says
that the limit should be around 50. so
that just gives you an idea of how bad
things are in some places a little
further out in the suburbs the levels
have reached 500 um and so you know
these measures that have come in what
while they are measures that are a step
in the right direction many people here
say are simply not enough to deal with
what is a long-standing problem this
isn't the first year i've talked to you
about this either on there it's
something that everybody in delhi has to
live with at this time of year
and it reflects the whole discussion
regarding climate change of course we
had cop 26 and that uh last minute
intervention by china and india in terms
of the rephrasing of coal how is all of
this being viewed by people who have to
get on with their lives there
well i think it's important to remind
our viewers what is the cause of this
toxic air that we're all breathing here
in delhi it's a combination of factors
people say now one of the factors is
industrial emissions and also vehicle
fumes traffic fumes but also at this
time of year what makes this uh kind of
a sharper focus is that farmers in
nearby states burn their crops to clear
the fields for the end of the year ready
for a new season and the fires as well
emit a lot of toxic fumes so that is
another factor
as well as people saying that in the
wake of diwali fireworks led off a lot
of smoke and that's also a trigger for
this time of year as the temperature's
cool as well with lots of dust in the
air now you have a lot of people
pointing fingers at each other and
saying this factors the biggest
contributor this fact is the biggest
contributor but all together it's a mix
that makes the air so filthy and foul
and the real challenge is how do you get
rid of that in the long term because you
know these measures there's even talk of
a full lockdown in delhi that won't be
uh for more than a few days maybe a week
or so if it comes in but it's not really
going to get to the heart of the problem
and i was talking to somebody from an
action group called warrior mums they're
mums in delhi who are really concerned
about the future of their children
because of the air that they breathe and
they say that the government needs to
get tough with everyone who might be
responsible for this
regina as always thanks so much for
bringing us up to date for talking us
through it and uh for being with us here
on live with kasha madeira regina
vardynathan they're speaking to us live
from delhi regarding that lots more
coming up in the next hour as well
from delhi too
